desc.size: Small tree or shrub, 2 - 7 m tall, trunk diameter 8 - 25 cm. Trunk often divided; crown irregular and asymmetrical, with many stiff, twisted, and intergrown branches.

part.partText: pale gray, thin, smooth, becoming warty, rough, and scaly with age.
slender, stiff, zigzag, green, becoming reddish brown to gray, smooth. Leaf scars crescent-shaped with 1 - 3 bundle scars.
grayish brown, 1 - 2 mm long, slender, oval, pointed, finely hairy.

alternate, with short, often hairy leafstalks; grayish green and smooth to finely hairy above, paler and hairy beneath; 4 - 6 cm long, 2.5 - 4 cm wide, egg-shaped; base rounded, moderately asymmetrical; tip short-pointed, margins with a few coarse teeth, thick, often leathery, 3 - 5 major veins per side.
either male or female, borne on the same tree (monoecious); in drooping clusters or solitary; greenish yellow, inconspicuous, without petals.
fleshy, single-seeded (drupe); borne on short, drooping stalks; pinkish brown to reddish purple, 5 - 7 mm long, spherical, smooth; pit smooth; persistent in winter.

similarSpecies.comments: Of the two Celtis species found in the Chicago Region, this one is rare. It can be distinguished from Celtis occidentalis by its smaller size, smaller, less-toothed, short-tipped leaves, smaller fruits on short (3 - 6 mm) stalks, and smooth, pinkish brown fruit. However, the leaves can be extremely variable, as some may or may not be as toothed, hairy, or leathery as others. Note: Leaves may resemble those of Ulmus, but Celtis species have three main veins arising from the base of each blade.

speciesPage.flowering: May, after the leaves are partly grown.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: In the Chicago Region, Celtis tenuifolia is known only to occur in Lake and Porter counties in Indiana. There it grows in the dune area of Lake Michigan, in calcareous sands near the lake. Outside the region, it is characteristic of dry-mesic to dry sites.

notes.comments: Although tenuifolia means “thin leaf,” the leaves actually vary in thickness. The wood is used for fence posts, but has no real commercial value.

etymology.comments: Celtis is the Greek word for the hackberry tree (hackberry is actually a corruption of the Scottish name Hagberry, a species of cherry tree). Tenuifolia is Latin for “thin leaf.”
